sent1: A 23-year-old black female named Latonya presents to a psychiatrist for evaluation of situational anxiety. She reports that she recently started a new job that involves regular public speaking and is very stressed before every public speaking event. She describes developing a rapid heart rate and diaphoresis that interferes with her ability to speak well. She has no past medical history and takes no medications. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she is well-appearing and appropriately conversational. She is alert and fully oriented. The female is prescribed propranolol to take before major public speaking events. Which of the following physiologic changes will occur when the female takes this medication?
ending0: Decreased cardiac output and decreased peripheral resistance
ending1: Decreased cardiac output and increased peripheral resistance
ending2: Increased cardiac output and decreased peripheral resistance
ending3: Increased cardiac output and increased peripheral resistance

A 24-year-old black female named Latonya is brought into the emergency room after being retrieved by firefighters from a burning building. The female is responding coherently to questions but reports pain secondary to a burn on her leg. She states she also has a headache and feels dizzy. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 129/66 mmHg, pulse is 126/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a confused young female with dry and flushed skin. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals a normal S1 and S2 as well as clear breath sounds bilaterally. The patient’s neurological exam is within normal limits. Towards the end of her exam, the female begins vomiting. Dermatologic exam reveals a superficial burn covering 1% of the patient’s body over her right leg. Which of the following is the best next step in management for this patient?

A 42-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency department because of several episodes of black, tarlike stool and lightheadedness over the past couple of days. She underwent an appendectomy at the age of 16. She has hypertension and tension headaches. She drinks 4 beers daily. Current medications include amlodipine and naproxen. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 100/min, and her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed, which does not show bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 73-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to her family practitioner by her daughter with the complaints of a spinning sensation for the past 4 weeks. She says that the room appears to be continuously spinning. This has progressively worsened over the last 4 weeks to the point that she has become bed bound and cannot walk without support. These spinning sensations are present throughout the day and do not change with position. They are associated with nausea and vomiting. She denies ear pain, ear discharge, ringing in the ear, hearing disturbances, ear fullness, head trauma, fever, or recent flu-like illness. She has a blood pressure of 133/80 mm Hg, heart rate of 80/min, respiratory rate of 12/min, and temperature of 36.7°C (98.2°F). Her extraocular eye movements are normal in all directions, but a vertical nystagmus is present that does not disappear despite repetitive testing. Hearing tests are within normal limits. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 70-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency department by staff of the group home where she resides because of fever, a productive cough, and blood-tinged sputum for 2 days. The staff report that she developed myalgia, headache, and rhinorrhea 7 days ago, which improved initially before worsening again. She has hypertension and Alzheimer disease. Current medications include enalapril and donepezil. On arrival, she is obtunded. Her temperature is 39.8°C (103.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 10 L/min of oxygen via nasal cannula shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows scattered crackles and rhonchi throughout both lung fields. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral lung opacities and multiple small, thin-walled cystic spaces within the basal pulmonary parenchyma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?

An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral lung opacities and multiple small, thin-walled cystic spaces within the basal pulmonary parenchyma. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?

A 43-year-old black female named Latonya presents to a new primary care physician complaining of anxiety. She has been worrying non-stop recently about the possibility that her partner will lose their job as a teacher. Her partner, who is present, assures the physician that their job is entirely secure and states that she has "fretted" for their entire marriage, though the exact topic causing her anxiety varies over time. She also worries excessively about everyday tasks, such as whether she will catch the train on time and whether their house in Southern California is sufficiently earthquake-proof. She has no way to overcome these worries. She endorses other symptoms including poor sleep (associated with racing thoughts about her various worries), fatigue, and impaired concentration at work, all of which have been present for at least the past year. Her vital signs are within normal limits and there are no abnormalities on physical exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 48-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the physician with a cough with expectoration and breathlessness on exertion for the last 4 years. There is no history of any other medical conditions. She has been a smoker for the last 10 years. She recently immigrated from a developing country and her immunization status is unknown. After a complete physical examination of the patient, the physician orders a chest radiogram which shows increased bronchovascular markings and flattening of the diaphragm. Her spirometry findings include an FEV1 of 82% of predicted, which increases to 88% of predicted at 15 minutes after the administration of inhaled albuterol. The FEV1/FVC ratio is 0.66. The physician explains the diagnosis to the female and emphasizes the importance of smoking cessation. She also offers them specific vaccinations. However, the female mentions that she does not have medical insurance and due to her poor financial situation, she can afford only 1 of the suggested vaccines. In such a situation, which of the following vaccines should definitely be recommended to this patient?

A 25-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency department by her partner for abdominal pain. The partner answers all questions posed to the female by the physician. Throughout the interview, the female makes very little eye contact with the physician. Her partner asks the physician to prescribe “something for her abdominal pain” so that they can return home. Examination of the female shows mild bruising in the left infraorbital area and a right periorbital hematoma. When asked about her injuries, she quietly states that she fell while walking down the stairwell of her apartment complex. The partner reluctantly leaves the examination room when asked to by the physician. While alone with the physician, the female admits that her partner is responsible for her injuries. Which of the following immediate responses by the physician is most appropriate?
ending0: May I add some information about local domestic violence agencies to your discharge records?
ending1: Do you feel safe leaving the emergency department?
ending2: How often has your partner physically hurt you in the past?
ending3: May I ask your partner to join us so we can talk about this matter together?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the physician after passing out at home. Her partner reports that she suddenly lost consciousness for approximately 30 seconds while shoveling snow in the driveway. Immediately before the episode, she felt light-headed and short of breath. Two months ago, she experienced a similar episode while running in her yard with her children. She has no history of serious illness. Her father died of sudden cardiac death at the age of 44 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur best heard along the left sternal border that decreases with hand grip. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

A 29-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care provider for a normal check-up at the prompting of her mother. When asked how she is doing, she replies that she feels depressed. Upon further questioning, she states that she feels “worthless” now that her ex-partner left them 2 days ago. She has been sitting in their bed all day trying to call them but she is not answering her calls. She says that she will never find another person like them and feels like she should just “disappear” rather than continue living without them. She also reports that she can hear their voice when they are not around, especially at night before she goes to bed. She denies having any other friends and has some social anxiety, particularly in large groups of people. A review of her medical record indicates that she has endured several episodes of verbal and physical abuse from her prior relationships which she suggested “were all her fault.” She has had 4 prior serious relationships and reports that she has not been single for more than a few days in the last 10 years. On exam, she is unkempt with poor self-care. This patient’s history is most consistent with which of the following conditions?

A 17-year-old black female named Latonya is presented to the clinic by her mom for hair loss. Both the female and her mom have noted random patches of hair loss across the female scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes, 1st appearing several months ago. The female has noticed no other symptoms, though the spots of hair loss are sometimes sore. On further questioning, the female shares that she has been very stressed lately about getting good grades and applying to colleges. She knows she needs to do well on all of her homework in order to get into a good college, so she has sometimes had to stay up late into the night to rewrite her homework over and over again so that they are 'absolutely perfect'. The physical exam shows an anxious-appearing, somewhat quiet There is diffuse hair loss and thinning across her scalp, with many different hair shafts of different lengths. There is no discernible pattern to the hair loss. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

Both the female and her mom have noted random patches of hair loss across the female scalp, eyebrows, and eyelashes, 1st appearing several months ago. The female has noticed no other symptoms, though the spots of hair loss are sometimes sore. On further questioning, the female shares that she has been very stressed lately about getting good grades and applying to colleges. She knows she needs to do well on all of her homework in order to get into a good college, so she has sometimes had to stay up late into the night to rewrite her homework over and over again so that they are 'absolutely perfect'. The physical exam shows an anxious-appearing, somewhat quiet There is diffuse hair loss and thinning across her scalp, with many different hair shafts of different lengths. There is no discernible pattern to the hair loss. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

A 49-year-old black female named Latonya visits the emergency department with the acute onset of severe shortness of breath. She also reports right-sided calf pain that developed after a 22-hour flight from Beijing to Los Angeles, and that, several hours after she felt pain in her calf, she began to have trouble breathing. Currently, her shortness of breath is so severe that she is unable to speak clearly or quickly, but she manages to deny any recent surgery or history of recent bleeding. The vital signs include: blood pressure 111/69 mm Hg, pulse 142/min, and respiratory rate 33/min. On observation, she is using accessory muscles to breathe. On auscultation, her lungs are clear and her heart rate is rapid but regular. Her right calf is swollen, warm, and tender. The arterial blood gas test result reveals a pH of 7.5, partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) 22 mm Hg, and a partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) 47 mm Hg on 6 L of oxygen by nasal cannula. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

A 37-year-old black female named Latonya comes to the emergency department because her eyes have had a yellow discoloration and she has had dark urine for the past 3 days. She has also had fever, itching, and severe fatigue. She reports having symptoms of the stomach flu a week ago, which resolved with over-the-counter medication. She does not have diarrhea but says her stools are whitish in appearance. She has no personal history of serious illness. She does not smoke and drinks an average of 2 beers on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. She has been sexually active with the same partner for 12 years and uses condoms consistently. She works as a flight attendant for an international airline. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 64/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus, excoriation marks over her extremities, and parched lips. The liver is tender on palpation; there is no splenomegaly. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.6 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,300/mm3 Platelet count 256,000/mm3 ESR 19 mm/hr Prothrombin time 13 seconds Serum Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Glucose 89 mg/dL Creatinine 0.7 mg/dL Bilirubin Total 8 mg/dL Direct 4 mg/dL ALP 80 U/L AST 312 U/L ALT 569 U/L An ultrasound of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Serum studies are most likely to show which of the following findings?

A 55-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician for back pain. The female states that her back pain is worse in the morning and improves with certain activities. She does not experience pain when cycling but notices the pain when standing or walking. 2 months prior to presentation she was lifting heavy boxes and furniture into her daughter's new home. She is requesting pain medication and a doctor's note to take off work for the week as her symptoms are disrupting her life. Which of the following is most likely to be seen in this patient?
ending0: Bamboo appearance of the spine on radiography
ending2: Multiple doctors visits for other unrelated problems
ending3: Narrowing of the lumbar spinal canal on MRI

A 25-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She is currently complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath and seems rather confused. Her temperature is 97.7°F (36.5°C), blood pressure is 94/54 mmHg, pulse is 170/min, respirations are 12/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. A 14-gauge needle is placed in the 2nd intercostal space on the patient’s left, and her blood pressure increases to 104/74 mmHg and her pulse decreases to 100/min. Which of the following is the best next intervention for this patient?

A 68-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency room because of pain in her right shoulder after falling down the stairs in her apartment. She has a history of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Her current medications are alendronate, vitamin D, and calcium supplementation. Physical examination shows shortening of the right arm as well as tenderness and swelling over the right shoulder. The range of motion of the right arm is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right shoulder shows a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. Which of the following movements is most likely to be impaired in this patient?

A 55-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department with recent onset confusion and photophobia. Upon questioning her partner, you discover the female has been sick over the past week with fevers and productive sputum. Her vital signs are Temperature 102.6 Pulse 80 Respirations 18 Blood Pressure 110/70. The physical exam is significant for lethargy and nuchal rigidity. A lumbar puncture is performed and demonstrates cloudy fluid with an opening pressure of 35 cm H20, cell count of 1500 cells/uL (neutrophil predominant), protein level of 50 mg/dL and glucose of 30 mg/dL. Computed tomography scan demonstrates no space-occupying lesions. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents with loss of consciousness at work. The patient’s colleagues say that she had been complaining of a headache all day. Her past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 1. Her blood pressure is 70/60 mm Hg, pulse is 105/min, temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and her respiratory rate is 28/min and shallow. On physical examination, there is a black eschar formation on her nose and her breath has a fruity odor. Laboratory findings are significant for serum glucose of 750 mg/dL, potassium of 3.3 mmol/L, and blood pH of 7.1. Which of the following diabetic complications is most likely the cause of this patient’s presenting symptoms?

A 55-year-old black female named Latonya presents with worsening weakness of the left hand and progressive difficulty in walking for the last 2 months. She says she was previously healthy and active, hiking every weekend, but because of her increasing weakness and incoordination while walking, she stopped her weekly hiking excursion. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Current medications are a daily multivitamin and occasional acetaminophen for headaches. She has no significant family history. The female denies smoking, recreational drug use, or drinking. Her vitals include: pulse 70/min, respirations 14/min, temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals fasciculations in the tongue and distal extremities. The left forearm shows significant atrophy, and mild lower limb muscle atrophy is also seen bilaterally. Hyporeflexia (1+) is present in the left arm, while hyperreflexia (3+) is seen in the legs bilaterally. Babinski’s sign is positive bilaterally. The patient's speech is notably slow but no evidence of productive or expressive aphasia is present. The cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following pathologies most likely underlies this patient’s condition?
ending0: Demyelination of neurons in various parts of the brain
ending1: Degeneration of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord
ending2: Infarction of the posterior limb of the internal capsule
ending3: Loss of the pyramidal tract neurons and anterior horn cells of the spinal cord

A 67-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her physician’s office with a progressive cough. It has been increasing in intensity over the past week. She has also been noticing an increase in the amount of sputum she usually produces, which is thick and yellow. She also complains of increased difficulty in breathing, more so than she previously experienced. She was diagnosed with chronic obstructive lung disease (COPD) about 3 years ago and has been on treatment for it since then. She doesn’t report any fever, chills, or night sweats. She has observed a foul smell to her sputum. Her blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, the respirations are 23/min and the pulse is about 110/min. Currently, her FEV1 is around 48% of the normal predicted value. She is currently receiving a yearly influenza shot and has taken the pneumococcal vaccination at the time of her diagnosis. In spite of this, she has had acute exacerbations of her symptoms 4 times over the last year. Her last episode was 2 months ago, for which she was treated with a short course of antibiotics. She is also currently receiving treatment for diabetes. Which of the following pathogens should be considered before initiating treatment for the current episode?

A 66-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician with abdominal pain in the setting of progressively worsening constipation. She complains of epigastric pain that waxes and wanes, and expressed concern that she has not defecated for the past 5 days. Upon further questioning, she relates that she has been taking three of her partner's multivitamins each day for the past three weeks to "combat a cold." Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical exam reveals an abdomen with nonspecific tenderness to deep palpation without rebound tenderness, hyperpercussion, or flank tenderness. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 70-year-old black female named Latonya comes to the physician because of fatigue and intermittent epigastric pain. The symptoms began about one year ago. She describes the pain as diffuse and 3 out of 10 in intensity. Recently, she has had unusually large black stools. She appears pale. Her pulse is 72/min and her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows epigastric tenderness. A urea breath test is positive. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals an ulcerating mass in the gastric antrum. Biopsies of the mass show diffuse infiltrates of small lymphoid cells that are positive for CD20 antigen. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows normal regional lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy with curative intent at this time?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents for follow up 3 months after starting an antiretroviral regimen consisting of efavirenz, tenofovir, and emtricitabine. Labs drawn just prior to presentation reveal an undetectable viral load and a T-lymphocyte count of 317/mm^3. By comparison, her viral load was 6100/mL and her T-lymphocyte count was 146/mm^3 at the time of treatment initiation. She reports that she is tolerating the medications well and is not experiencing any major side effects. Which of the following treatment regimens should be recommended for this female given the fully suppressed viral load?
ending0: Continue current regimen of efavirenz, tenofovir, and emtricitabine
ending1: Continue efavirenz and emtricitabine but discontinue tenofovir
ending2: Continue efavirenz and tenofovir but discontinue emtricitabine
ending3: Continue tenofovir and emtricitabine but discontinue efavirenz

sent1: A 55-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician with a 2-month history of fatigue. She says that she has been feeling tired, even after mild exertion, and decided to be evaluated because it has begun interfering with her job as a construction worker. She reports that she has been feeling numbness and tingling in her feet and has been tripping more frequently. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes well-controlled on metformin. Her surgical history is significant for weight-loss surgery 2 years ago. Physical exam reveals bilateral vibration sensory deficits as well as conjunctival pallor. Selected lab results are presented as follows: Hemoglobin: 9.1 g/dL Hematocrit: 27% Platelet count: 265,000/mm^3 Mean corpuscular volume: 112 µm^3 Reticulocyte count: 0.19% Which of the following findings would most likely also be seen in this patient?
ending1: High methylmalonic acid and high homocysteine levels

sent1: A 73-year-old black female named Latonya with a past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with swelling in her left neck. Physical examination reveals a painless swelling in front of her left ear. There is painless lymphadenopathy below the ear. A 72-year-old black female named Latonya is brought in by ambulance after being found down in her home. Her daughter discovered them after returning from work and does not know how long she has been down. Physical exam reveals right sided paralysis with a positive babinski sign. She is also found to produce strained stuttering speech with no perceivable meaning. She is unable to follow any instructions and cannot repeat speech. An MRI is obtained showing a left MCA infarct. Damage to which of the following structures is most likely to be responsible for her language deficits?
ending2: Inferior frontal gyrus + superior temporal gyrus
ending3: Arcuate fasciculus + Inferior frontal gyrus + superior temporal gyrus

sent1: A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department with complaints of acute-onset fatigue, blurred vision, and rash earlier today. Her partner rushed them to the emergency department when they noted that she was exhibiting changes in her mental status and had trouble speaking. Her vital signs are as follows: T 38.4, HR 87, BP 110/85, RR 14, and SpO2 96%. Physical examination reveals petechiae, pallor, and left upper extremity weakness. Work-up reveals Hgb 8.5 g/dL, platelets 22,000 cells/uL, normal PT/INR and PTT, absent fibrin split products, elevated fibrinogen, a negative Coombs test, 3.7 mg/dL creatinine, 3.8 mg/dL indirect bilirubin, and LDH 1000 IU/L. Which of the following would be expected on a peripheral blood smear from this patient?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents with diarrhea, fatigue and weight loss. She says she has been having occasional loose stools and abdominal pain for the past month, but she did not seek any medical attention because of work deadlines. She says the diarrhea is associated with cramping lower abdominal pain and an urgency to defecate. Her stool is loose, occasionally blood-tinged, and contains mucus. She also says she feels fatigued and has lost 11 kg (24 lb) over the last 2 months. The female denies any fever, sick contacts, or a history of recent travel. No significant past medical history. Family history is significant for colon cancer in her father, who died at the age of 50. On physical examination, the female has generalized pallor. Abdominal exam reveals mild tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic anemia with an elevated ESR. A colonoscopy with biopsy is performed, which shows inflammation of the sigmoid colon and rectum. Biopsy shows a predominantly lymphoid infiltration of the mucosa and submucosa with multiple crypt abscesses. No evidence of granulomatous disease. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which typically induces remission of this patient’s most likely condition?
ending0: Inhibition of prostaglandins and inflammatory cytokines

Biopsy shows a predominantly lymphoid infiltration of the mucosa and submucosa with multiple crypt abscesses. No evidence of granulomatous disease. What is the mechanism of action of the drug which typically induces remission of this patient’s most likely condition?
ending0: Inhibition of prostaglandins and inflammatory cytokines

sent1: A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department with a chief concern of abdominal pain and diarrhea. The female states that for the past 4 days she has experienced abdominal pain, diarrhea, weakness and a subjective fever. She also endorses a weight loss of 11 pounds during this time. The female has a past medical history of celiac disease, constipation, and depression. Her current medications include fish oil, a multivitamin, sodium docusate, and fluoxetine. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 13/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Oral exam is notable for multiple shallow painful ulcers. The female is started on IV fluids and morphine. Which of the following best describes the most likely diagnosis?
ending2: Dilated vascular structure in the anal canal

She also notices that her stools are dark. She has had essential hypertension for 20 years for which she takes bisoprolol. Her family history is positive for type 2 diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, she looks pale. Complete blood count shows the following: Hemoglobin 10 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 70 fL Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH) 25 pg/cell Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) 27 g/dL Red cell distribution width 16% Platelet count 350,000/mm3 Serum ferritin is 9 ng/mL. A preoperative staging is performed and a laparoscopic cancer resection with postoperative chemotherapy are planned. Which of the following tests can be used for postoperative follow up of this patient?

A 36-year-old black female named Latonya presents with a persistent cough productive of blood-streaked sputum, night sweats, and weight loss. No significant past medical history. She denies any history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or recreational drug use. She works as a nurse at a local hospital and lives in an apartment with her extended family. Her vital signs are a blood pressure of 100/80 mm Hg, heart rate of 94/min, respiratory rate of 17/min, and temperature of 35.9℃ (96.6℉). Physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds over the upper lobe of the left lung. During the discussion regarding the required workup, the female tells the physician about recent contact with a female with tuberculosis. She asks the physician not to report her case because she is concerned she will lose her job. Which of the following statements is correct?
ending0: If this patient is diagnosed with active pulmonary tuberculosis, it should be reported even without the patient’s consent, and the patient should receive isolation and treatment.
ending1: The patient has a right to privacy, so, without their consent, the physician can not report their case even if they are diagnosed with active pulmonary tuberculosis.
ending2: If this patient turns out to have active pulmonary tuberculosis, their case can stay unreported only if they agree to stay home from work and remain isolated at home for their entire treatment period.
ending3: Only active pulmonary tuberculosis is a reportable disease.

sent1: A 30-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the doctor's office by her partner. They complain that over the past week there have been 3 episodes where she has fallen asleep while speaking with [her]. They mentioned that these events began a few months ago and have been increasing in frequency. They also say that her snoring has gotten to the point where they have a hard time sleeping next to them. When asked, the female says that she frequently falls asleep while reading or watching television in the afternoons and feels refreshed after a short nap. The female is worried because she sometimes hears people who aren’t in the room as she falls asleep. She is worried she might be “going crazy.” She has noticed that when her friends tell them a joke or she laughs at something on the TV, she drops whatever she is holding and feels like her legs become weak. These episodes self-resolve in a few seconds. Examination shows a morbidly obese female in no acute distress. Which of the following is the best treatment for the most likely cause for this patient’s illness?
ending3: Changing bedtime to earlier in the evening

A 17-year-old black female named Latonya is brought in by paramedics to the emergency department. She was found down at a family picnic. The female parents state that she tried many new foods at the picnic. Additionally, because it is springtime, many insects were out while she was playing football. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 33/min, and oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. Physical exam is notable for tachycardia and very minimal breath sounds bilaterally. No jugular venous distention is noted and an abdominal exam is within normal limits. Which of the following best describes an effect of the next best step in management?
ending1: Equilibration of environmental and chest cavity pressure

A 23-year-old black female named Latonya develops a seizure on the medical floor. She was admitted 2 days ago with high-grade fever and severe headache. At the time of admission, she had photophobia, neck rigidity, and the following vital signs: temperature 39.5°C (103.1°F), blood pressure 130/70 mm Hg, and heart rate 120/min. A cerebral spinal fluid analysis was ordered, and she was started on intravenous antibiotics. The patient’s seizure terminates without any medication or intervention. An MRI is performed which reveals dilation of all the ventricles of the brain. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her abnormal radiologic findings?
ending0: Blood clot in the foramen of 3rd ventricle

sent1: A 60-year-old black female named Latonya calls her hospital and asks to speak to her physician about laboratory test reports ordered because of a 3-month history of abdominal fullness and generalized fatigue. The referral note shows that she was constipated for the previous week. Her abdominal examination had shown distention, and a 7-cm, hard, irregular, nontender mass was palpable on rectal examination. Her colonoscopy report reveals a low anterior circumferential rectal lesion. An MRI of the pelvis shows a rectal mass with involvement of the prostate and seminal vesicles. A brief review of the results shows that an endoscopic biopsy confirms the clinical diagnosis of advanced rectal adenocarcinoma. Her serum carcinoembryonic antigen concentration is 21.0 ng/mL (N < 2.5). The physician is tasked with delivering the diagnosis to the patient. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement by the physician at this time?
ending0: Your lab reports show that you have a locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma
ending1: Would you like to know all the details of your diagnosis, or would you prefer I just explain to you what our options are?
ending2: I would like to meet later today at 4:00 PM so that we have enough time to discuss the lab results. If you'd like a friend or family member to accompany you, feel free to bring them along.
ending3: You must be be curious as to why all these tests were ordered, and you may even be anxious about the results.

sent1: A 39-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency room by her partner for severe abdominal pain for the past 5 hours. She was watching TV after dinner when she felt a sudden, sharp, 10/10 pain at the epigastric region that did not go away. Ibuprofen also did not help. She reports recurrent abdominal pain that would self-resolve in the past but states that “this one is way worse.” Her past medical history is significant for diabetes and an appendectomy 2 years ago. The female endorses nausea and 1 episode of emesis, but denies fevers, chills, chest pain, shortness of breath, diarrhea, constipation, urinary symptoms, paresthesia, or weakness. She used to smoke marijuana in college and drinks about 2 beers a week. A physical examination demonstrates an overweight female in acute distress with diffuse abdominal tenderness. Her vitals are within normal limits. Laboratory values are shown below: Hemoglobin: 12 g/dL Hematocrit: 34% Leukocyte count: 4,900/mm^3 with normal differential Platelet count: 160,000/mm^3 Serum: Na+: 138 mEq/L Cl-: 98 mEq/L K+: 4.8 mEq/L HCO3-: 25 mEq/L Glucose: 123 mg/dL Ca2+: 6.9 mg/dL AST: 387 U/L ALT: 297 U/L ALP: 168 U/L Lipase: 650 U/L (Normal 0 – 160 U/L) What is the best next step in the workup of this patient?
ending0: Abdominal computed tomography without IV contrast

sent1: A 37-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician with a chief complaint of diarrhea. The female states that her symptoms have worsened recently. She works as a farmer and is dressed in tattered and old denim. She lives alone, and this is the first time she has come to town in years. The patient’s diet is mostly dairy products and some meat products. She denies any systemic symptoms and states that diarrhea tends to occur right after a meal. She also claims that at times she struggles to fall asleep, and sometimes she feels she lacks energy. The female is instructed to avoid consuming dairy products for a week and to return with a report of her symptoms. As you set up the return appointment with this female you notice that she is rather emotionless. She also states that she lacks anybody that she can list as an emergency contact so she leaves that section of her medical forms blank. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician’s office with fatigue, headaches, and concentration difficulties. Her symptoms began approximately 7 months prior to presentation. Throughout this time, she reports problems with initiating and remaining asleep, has noticed periods of muscle soreness, and has feelings of restlessness. She states that she is very concerned about whether she will be able to pay her monthly expenses and if her parents are satisfied with her career choices. She is also worried about how her colleagues and supervisor think of her performance at work. She denies any significant past medical history besides occasional palpitations. She takes a daily multivitamin. Family history is significant for panic disorder in her mother. She currently lives alone and at times socializes with friends. She occasionally drinks alcohol during social gatherings, does not smoke, and denies any illicit drug use. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2 °C), blood pressure is 110/75, pulse is 101/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment for this patient?

A 65-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the Emergency Department complaining of substernal chest pain. An acute coronary event is suspected and a coronary catheterization procedure reveals an atherosclerotic plaque in the patient's left anterior descending artery. In the formation of an atherosclerotic plaque, which of the following pairings is correct?
ending1: Smooth muscle cells (SMC) -- extracellular matrix (ECM) deposition

sent1: A 26-year-old black female named Latonya comes to the physician because of high-grade fever, fatigue, nausea, and headache for 4 days. The headache is constant and feels like a tight band around her head. She also reports that her eyes hurt while looking at bright lights. She has been taking acetaminophen and using cold towels to help relieve her symptoms. She works as an assistant for a nature camp organization but has been unable to go to work for 3 days. Her immunization records are unavailable. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 108/74 mm Hg. She is oriented to time, place, and person. There is no rash or lymphadenopathy. Flexion of the neck results in flexion of the knee and hip. A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an opening pressure of 80 mm H2O, leukocyte count of 93/mm3 (78% lymphocytes), a glucose concentration of 64 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 50 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

A lumbar puncture is done; cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows an opening pressure of 80 mm H2O, leukocyte count of 93/mm3 (78% lymphocytes), a glucose concentration of 64 mg/dL, and a protein concentration of 50 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?

A 42-year-old black female named Latonya is being treated by her female family medicine physician for chronic depression. Recently, she has been scheduling more frequent office visits. She does not report any symptoms or problems with her SSRI medication during these visits. Upon further questioning, the female confesses that she is attracted to them and says “You are the only one in the world who understands me“. The physician also manages her hypertension. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
ending0: Re-evaluate this patient for borderline personality disorder
ending1: Ask closed-ended questions and use a chaperone for future visits
ending2: Immediately tell this patient that you can not continue to treat them and avoid any further communication
ending3: Increase the dosage of this patient’s SSRI

sent1: A 52-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician for her annual check-up. She says that she has no health concerns; however, her partner is concerned that she has become increasingly forgetful. For example, she has become forgetful during her daily activities and recently has been getting lost during errands like shopping. She says that these symptoms have been occurring for about a year. She says that she became alarmed when she started forgetting the names of their children. Finally, over the last month she has become more irritable, which has led to several confrontations at work. Based on the age of onset for her disease, the female is referred for genetic testing. Which of the following chromosomes contain genes that may be mutated in this patient's disease?

A 68-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician for pain in her feet. The female states that it is very painful for them to walk around, and she has significant pain in her right and left toes. The female has a past medical history of obesity, type II diabetes mellitus, anxiety, depression, COPD, and a 30 pack-year smoking history. The patient’s current medications include lisinopril, hydrochlorothiazide, insulin, metformin, fluoxetine, clonazepam, albuterol, home oxygen, varenicline, and fish oil and she is compliant with all medications. On a physical exam, the patient’s toes appear pale and dirty. When inspecting her toes, shallow wounds with a pale base devoid of granulation tissue can be appreciated. The female has decreased pinprick sensation in her lower extremities bilaterally. Pulmonary exam is notable for a prolonged expiratory phase. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found in this patient?
ending1: Increased reflexes of the lower extremities
ending2: Loss of vibration sensation in the lower extremities
ending3: Calf pain after walking moderate distance

sent1: A 52-year-old black female named Latonya with limited, unresectable small cell lung cancer comes to the emergency department because of fever for the past 2 days. A 66-year-old black female named Latonya presents to clinic for a blood glucose level of 169 mg/dL taken at a local pharmacy. She is a farmer in rural Alabama and has not seen a doctor for decades. She wants to be in excellent shape prior to her trip to visit her daughter at college. Her past medical history and family history are unknown, and she does not take any medications. Her diet consists of pork products and she does not smoke. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 100/min, blood pressure is 169/90 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The female is started on metformin, lisinopril, and a guided exercise program. Lab results are below: Serum: Na+: 145 mEq/L Cl-: 100 mEq/L K+: 4.9 mEq/L HCO3-: 24 mEq/L BUN: 18 mg/dL Glucose: 211 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL Ca2+: 10.0 mg/dL He returns from her trip, complaining of cough. She denies any other symptoms. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 101/min, blood pressure is 160/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Repeat lab results are below: Serum: Na+: 145 mEq/L Cl-: 100 mEq/L K+: 5.3 mEq/L HCO3-: 24 mEq/L BUN: 22 mg/dL Glucose: 169 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL Ca2+: 10.1 mg/dL What is the next best step in management?
ending0: Switch blood pressure medication to losartan
ending1: Switch blood pressure medication to hydrochlorothiazide

sent1: A 36-year-old black female named Latonya presents with right upper quadrant pain, fatigue, and pruritus. ending2: Mononuclear cell infiltrate and apoptotic hepatocytes

Her past medical history is significant for ulcerative colitis diagnosed 5 years ago, which is well-managed medically. She is vaccinated against hepatitis A and B and denies any recent travel abroad. On physical examination, mild jaundice of the skin is present. An abdominal examination reveals significant hepatosplenomegaly. A percutaneous liver biopsy is performed. Which of the following histopathologic findings would most likely be seen on the liver biopsy of this patient?
ending0: Small drops of fat throughout the liver parenchyma
ending2: Mononuclear cell infiltrate and apoptotic hepatocytes

sent1: A 25-year-old black female named Latonya is brought by her roommate to the emergency department with chest pain, which began 90 minutes ago. On examination, she is diaphoretic, extremely agitated, and attempts to remove her IV lines and ECG leads. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.2°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 160/102 mmHg. A 50-year-old black female named Latonya comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of intermittent watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. She has had a 12-kg (26-lb) weight loss during this period. She has also had episodic pain of the ankle, wrist, and knee joints during the past 5 years. An endoscopy with small bowel biopsy is performed. Histopathologic examination of a tissue specimen shows foamy macrophages in the lamina propria with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive inclusions. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
ending3: Low serum TSH and high free T4 concentrations

sent1: A 55-year-old homeless black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department acutely confused. The female was found wandering the streets with an abnormal gait. The female has a past medical history of alcohol and IV drug abuse. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 103/61 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a poorly kempt female with ataxic gait. Ophthalmoplegia is noted on cranial nerve testing, and she has decreased vibration sensation in the bilateral lower extremity. Dermatologic exam reveals perifollicular hemorrhages, bleeding gums, and many bruises along the patient’s upper and lower extremities. An initial ECG is notable for sinus tachycardia and the female is given 2L of Ringer lactate. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below. Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL Hematocrit: 30% Leukocyte count: 3,500/mm^3 with normal differential Platelet count: 192,000/mm^3 MCV: 119 fL Serum: Na+: 139 mEq/L Cl-: 100 mEq/L K+: 4.3 mEq/L HCO3-: 25 mEq/L BUN: 20 mg/dL Glucose: 47 mg/dL Creatinine: 1 mg/dL Ca2+: 9.2 mg/dL Mg2+: 1.2 mEq/L AST: 82 U/L ALT: 70 U/L Which of the following is the best next treatment for this patient?

Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL Hematocrit: 30% Leukocyte count: 3,500/mm^3 with normal differential Platelet count: 192,000/mm^3 MCV: 119 fL Serum: Na+: 139 mEq/L Cl-: 100 mEq/L K+: 4.3 mEq/L HCO3-: 25 mEq/L BUN: 20 mg/dL Glucose: 47 mg/dL Creatinine: 1 mg/dL Ca2+: 9.2 mg/dL Mg2+: 1.2 mEq/L AST: 82 U/L ALT: 70 U/L Which of the following is the best next treatment for this patient?

A 55-year-old homeless black female named Marva presents to the emergency department acutely confused. The female was found wandering the streets with an abnormal gait. The female has a past medical history of alcohol and IV drug abuse. Her temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 103/61 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a poorly kempt female with ataxic gait. Ophthalmoplegia is noted on cranial nerve testing, and she has decreased vibration sensation in the bilateral lower extremity. Dermatologic exam reveals perifollicular hemorrhages, bleeding gums, and many bruises along the patient’s upper and lower extremities. An initial ECG is notable for sinus tachycardia and the female is given 2L of Ringer lactate. Laboratory values are ordered as seen below. Hemoglobin: 8.0 g/dL Hematocrit: 30% Leukocyte count: 3,500/mm^3 with normal differential Platelet count: 192,000/mm^3 MCV: 119 fL Serum: Na+: 139 mEq/L Cl-: 100 mEq/L K+: 4.3 mEq/L HCO3-: 25 mEq/L BUN: 20 mg/dL Glucose: 47 mg/dL Creatinine: 1 mg/dL Ca2+: 9.2 mg/dL Mg2+: 1.2 mEq/L AST: 82 U/L ALT: 70 U/L Which of the following is the best next treatment for this patient?

A 29-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at home. The patient's roommate says that the female had previously been feeling well. The female and her roommate had a celebration the night before, where they drank homemade liquor. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 126/min, respirations are 30/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 84/44 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. She is unresponsive to painful stimuli. The pupils are 3 mm, equal, round, and reactive to light. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a grade 2/6 systolic murmur along the left parasternal border. Laboratory studies show: Serum Na+ 146 mmol/L K+ 7.7 mmol/L Cl- 111 mmol/L Urea nitrogen 5.8 mmol/L Glucose 83 mg/dL Lactate 11.2 mmol/L Serum osmolality 379 mosm/kg Arterial blood gas analysis shows: pH 6.69 pCO2 53 mm Hg pO2 84 mm Hg HCO3- 4.3 mmol/L The female is intubated and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

A 24-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the ED from a nearby nightclub by the local police due to aggressive and violent behavior over the past hour. A friend accompanying the female reports that the female smoked marijuana that "seemed different" approximately one hour ago. The female has never had this kind of reaction to marijuana use in the past. On examination, the female is combative with slurred speech and active visual hallucinations; eye examination shows prominent vertical nystagmus. This patient's presentation can be best explained by intoxication with a substance that acts at which of the following receptors?

A 57-year-old black female named Latonya comes to the emergency department 1 hour after experiencing a distressing 10-minute episode of stuttering during a business meeting. She has hypertension. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include fosinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 134/88 mm Hg. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her speech is clear. When she is asked to hold both arms fully extended at shoulder level with palms upwards and eyes closed, her right palm turns inwards and downwards. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's physical findings?

A 36-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her primary care physician for her yearly physical exam. She says that she has been experiencing some mild shortness of breath, but otherwise has no medical complaints. Her past medical history is significant for allergies and asthma as a child, but she is not currently taking any medications or supplements. She does not smoke and drinks about 2 glasses of wine per week as a social activity. On a physical exam she is asked to take deep breaths during cardiac auscultation. The physician notices that the splitting of S2 decreases during inspiration. Which of the following is most consistent with this physical exam finding?

A 27-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency department with severe wheezing, which started an hour ago. She informs the doctor that she has had mild persistent asthma for the last 2 years and is on inhaled corticosteroids, and uses them regularly. She has not experienced asthma symptoms for the last 2 months and there is no history of non-compliance. She mentions that her present symptoms came on about 20 minutes after her last meal. When the doctor makes specific inquiries, she recollects items in her lunch, which included canned milk product, commercially available roasted peanuts, homemade celery salad, and wine. She has never developed respiratory symptoms in response to milk protein, peanuts, or acetaminophen until now. Skin prick testing for food allergens, performed a month back, was negative for all the common food allergens, including milk and peanuts. Which of the following is the most likely trigger for the patient’s current episode?

A 47-year-old black female named Latonya is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after her neighbor found them collapsed on her front porch in a pool of vomitus. On arrival, she is oriented only to self. Her pulse is 103/min and respirations are 30/min. Neurologic examination shows muscle spasms in the arms and jaw. Serum studies show: Na+ 137 mEq/L Cl- 99 mEq/L HCO3- 8 mEq/L Osmolality 328 mOsm/kg The difference between the calculated and observed serum osmolality is 32 mOsm/kg. Urinalysis shows oxalate crystals. This female is most likely experiencing toxicity from which of the following substances?

A 68-year-old black female named Latonya presents to the emergency room with productive cough and fever. She has a chronic cough that has been getting progressively worse over the last 2 weeks. Last night she developed a fever and vomited. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 40 years and recently quit. Her past medical history includes COPD and her medications include ipratropium and fluticasone. On physical exam her temperature is 102.2°F (39°C), blood pressure is 131/78 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. She has decreased breath sounds bilaterally with diffuse crackles. You obtain a sputum sample and identify an organism that grows selectively on medium containing factors V and X. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A 47-year-old black female named Latonya presents to her ophthalmologist for abnormal vision. The female was discharged from the hospital 2 weeks ago after a motor vehicle accident where she was given 1L of blood. She also underwent several surgical procedures including enucleation of the right globe and exploratory abdominal laparotomy to stop internal bleeding. Currently, she states that she has noticed decreased vision in her left eye. The female has a past medical history of poorly controlled diabetes, asthma, and atopic dermatitis. Her temperature is 98.9°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 167/108 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. A 41-year-old black female named Latonya presents with progressive fatigue, pain in the front of the chest, and difficulty breathing with minimal exertion while trying to sleep. She reports having a flu-like illness consisting of fatigue, muscle pain, and cough 10 days ago that resolved spontaneously without seeking medical help. She has no past medical history. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Her vital signs include a blood pressure of 100/70 mm Hg, a temperature of 37.5°C (99.5°F), and a regular radial pulse of 105/min. On physical examination, the female looks tired, the jugular venous pressure is elevated, pulmonary rales are present on both sides, and an S3 gallop is audible. Her ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave abnormalities. A 2-dimensional echocardiogram shows global left ventricular motion abnormalities and dilatation of the left ventricle. Troponin I and Creatine Kinase-MB are elevated. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of the female illness?
ending0: Rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque in the coronary artery
ending1: Viral-mediated inflammation with local and systemic immunological activation
ending2: Infection of the endocardial surface of the heart with microembolization and immune complex deposition
ending3: Immune-mediated inflammation of the heart triggered by a preceding streptococcal infection
